Matthias, I may have missed it in the long thread, but did you say
your out=
put is in degrees?  Is it a delta request, i.e. is it a
requested change, o=
r is it an absolute angle that is requested?  

My suggestion is to allow o=
utputs to request only very small
incremental changes in angle, such as "mo=
ve one degree up" or "move
one degree down" at maximum.  If there are enoug=
h time steps per
second, then it should move to the correct angle in reason=
able time.

However, perhaps I misunderstood how your output works.  If so,=
 how
are you interpreting the output?

ken


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "=
matthias.linhardt" <faulerlennert@...>
wrote:
>
> Good morning everyone!
> =
Thanks a lot, Colin, these were very good ideas you had! I spent the 
> who=
le day and night checking everything, but I haven't found my 
> mistake so =
far. But I made some interesting discoveries, which I hope 
> help me find =
the culprit or at least point me in the right direction. 
> I tried differe=
nt settings with the 1joint condition and everything 
> worked out fine (ag=
ainst my earlier expectations). 
> 1. I started with the easiest task: 3 ra=
ndom start angles (0=B0-180=B0), 
> 1 goal angle (90=B0). Time elapsed unti=
l perfect movement was observed: 
> 30 generations.
> 2a. 3 random start an=
gles (0=B0-180=B0), 3 differnt goal angles (45=B0, 
> 90=B0, 135=B0). 50 ge=
nerations until perfect behavior.
> 2b. Same as 2a, but with 12 random star=
t angles. 70 generations.
> 3. 3 random start angles (0=B0-180=B0), 3 rando=
m goal angles (30=B0-150=B0). 
> 90 generations.
> 
> Although more generat=
ions were needed with increasing task complexity 
> (and I think the time n=
eeded is appropriate, taking into account that 
> gravity has to be masterd=
, or am I wrong?), all of the above tasks 
> was solved with very good resu=
lting behaviour. Then I started to add 
> a second joint and suddenly every=
thing was back to normal (which in 
> my case means: bad). 
> 4. 1st joint:=
 3 random start and 3 random goal angles (0=B0-180=B0). 2nd 
> joint: 3 ran=
dom start and 3 random goal angles (0=B0-360=B0). Observed 
> behaviour: un=
til generation 50 fast improvements, generation 50-100 
> minor improvement=
s, generation 100-600 no improvements at all.
> 
> Judging from the above m=
entioned data, I would suggest two 
> possibilites:
> A. The 1st joint work=
s well, meaning I made a mistake concerning the 
> 2nd joint (and all follo=
wing) which makes it impossible for NEAT to 
> solve the problem (e.g. not =
all of the necessary input is provided).
> B. There is a more general mista=
ke I made, resulting in lower 
> performance with increasing task complexit=
y and concerning not only 
> the 2nd joint but all joints in general (e.g. =
an error in the 
> communication between NEAT and the simulator).
> 
> Pers=
onally, I would vote for A, so as long as nobody disagrees (for 
> example,=
 because you think the 1st joint should learn much faster 
> these easy tas=
ks), I will try some easier tasks with 2joints (like 
> the ones with 1join=
t, e.g. with one joint having a non-random goal 
> angle) in order to narro=
w down the field.
> 
> I can't thank you guys enough, it's very good to hav=
e someone with 
> fresh ideas listening to one's problems. I was really des=
perated as I 
> made no progress at all over the last weeks, but now I'm fu=
ll of hope 
> to get it right in the end.
> With best regards,
> Matthias
>=
